articles.headline: S.E.C. Charges 5 Firms Over Audits in China
articles.snippet: The Securities and Exchange Commission says the Chinese affiliates of the five largest United States accounting firms failed to produce work papers from their audits of several China-based companies that are under investigation.
articles.abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission says the Chinese affiliates of the five largest United States accounting firms failed to produce work papers from their audits of several China-based companies that are under investigation.

articles.headline: Border Agents’ Power to Search Devices Is Facing Increasing Challenges in Court
articles.snippet: Broad search powers at the border are being challenged as more people travel with personal and business information on devices that would typically require a warrant to examine.
articles.abstract: Broad search powers at the border are being challenged as more people travel with personal and business information on devices that would typically require a warrant to examine.
articles.lead_paragraph: The government has historically had broad power to search travelers and their property at the border. But that prerogative is being challenged as more people travel with extensive personal and business information on devices that would typically require a warrant to examine.

articles.headline: For Buffett, the Long Run Still Trumps the Quick Return
articles.snippet: In New York to promote a new book about him, Warren E. Buffett lamented Wall Street, which promotes a trading culture over an investing culture.
articles.abstract: In New York to promote a new book about him, Warren E. Buffett lamented Wall Street, which promotes a trading culture over an investing culture.
articles.lead_paragraph: “If somebody bought Berkshire Hathaway in 1965 and they held it, they made a great investment — and their broker would have starved to death.”

articles.headline: Ruling Is Victory for Drug Companies in Promoting Medicine for Other Uses
articles.snippet: The federal appellate decision overturned the conviction of a sales representative who said a ban on promotion of unapproved uses violated his freedom of speech.
articles.abstract: The federal appellate decision overturned the conviction of a sales representative who said a ban on promotion of unapproved uses violated his freedom of speech.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a case that could have broad ramifications for the pharmaceutical industry, a federal appeals court on Monday threw out the conviction of a sales representative who sold a drug for uses not approved by the Food and Drug Administration. The judges said that the ban on so-called off-label marketing violated the representative’s freedom of speech.

articles.headline: Generic Drug Makers See a Drought Ahead
articles.snippet: More than 40 brand-name drugs lost patents this year, but generic drug makers have been scrambling to make up revenue next year when far fewer patents expire.
articles.abstract: More than 40 brand-name drugs lost patents this year, but generic drug makers have been scrambling to make up revenue next year when far fewer patents expire.
articles.lead_paragraph: They call it the patent cliff.

articles.headline: Pakistan Reels With Violence Against Shiites
articles.snippet: More than 100 Hazaras have been killed by Sunni extremist gunmen this year, many in broad daylight.
articles.abstract: More than 100 Hazaras have been killed by Sunni extremist gunmen this year, many in broad daylight.
articles.lead_paragraph: QUETTA, Pakistan — Calligraphers linger at the gates of an ancient graveyard in this brooding city in western Pakistan, charged with a macabre and increasingly in-demand task: inscribing the tombstones of the latest victims of the sectarian death squads that openly roam these streets.

articles.headline: High-Speed Traders Profit at Expense of Ordinary Investors, a Study Says
articles.snippet: A top government economist has concluded that high-speed trading firms are taking significant profits from traditional investors.
articles.abstract: A top government economist has concluded that high-speed trading firms are taking significant profits from traditional investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: A top government economist has concluded that the high-speed trading firms that have come to dominate the nation’s financial markets are taking significant profits from traditional investors.
articles.byline: By Nathaniel Popper and Christopher Leonard

articles.headline: Michigan Town Woos Hollywood, but Ends Up With a Bit Part
articles.snippet: A studio was built to attract filmmakers and bring jobs to Pontiac, Mich., but for millions given in incentives to the film industry, only a handful of local jobs have appeared.
articles.abstract: A studio was built to attract filmmakers and bring jobs to Pontiac, Mich., but for millions given in incentives to the film industry, only a handful of local jobs have appeared.
articles.lead_paragraph: PONTIAC, Mich. — Even the great and powerful Oz could not save the film studio that was supposed to save this town.

articles.headline: More Dads Buy the Toys, So Barbie, and Stores, Get Makeovers
articles.snippet: Fathers are doing more of the family shopping just as girls are being steered toward toys that develop math skills.
articles.abstract: Fathers are doing more of the family shopping just as girls are being steered toward toys that develop math skills.
articles.lead_paragraph: Barbies are for girls and construction sets are for boys. Or are they?

articles.headline: Assad Suffering Reversals in Fighting and Diplomacy
articles.snippet: As the battle for the Syrian capital worsened, a Turkish official said that Russia had agreed to try a new approach to persuade President Bashar al-Assad to relinquish power.
articles.abstract: As the battle for the Syrian capital worsened, a Turkish official said that Russia had agreed to try a new approach to persuade President Bashar al-Assad to relinquish power.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Fierce fighting on the battlefield and setbacks on the diplomatic front increased pressure on the embattled Syrian government on Monday as fresh signs emerged of a worsening battle for control of the capital.
articles.byline: By Anne Barnard and Ellen Barry

articles.headline: Republicans Balk at Short-Term Stimulus in Obama Plan
articles.snippet: The president claims the economy needs a shot in the arm now, but Republicans say the nation should not widen the deficit.
articles.abstract: The president claims the economy needs a shot in the arm now, but Republicans say the nation should not widen the deficit.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republicans and Democrats are struggling to find common ground on a long-term debt deal. But as economic growth has weakened this quarter, they are at odds over what the flagging recovery needs in the immediate future, too.
